authors.headline: PhD Candidate at Wageningen University & Research

profile_positions.description:
Research has shown that dietetic intervention in patients with obesity and comorbidity can be effective. However, effectivity differs per individual and many patients stop treatment prematurely. 
Furthermore, it is unclear which components of the dietetic treatment result in success. What works? For whom? Under what conditions and why does it work? These are questions that I am researching in my PhD research project Dietetics, building the future. 

'Dietetics building the future' is a national research consortium that consists of Wageningen University & Research, Erasmus MC, Haagse Hogeschool, Hanzehogeschool Groningen, Hogeschool van Amsterdam, Hogeschool Arnhem en Nijmegen (HAN), the Dutch society of dietitians (NVD) and various organisations from the dietetic work field in the Netherlands. 

Visit the LinkedIn page of Dietetics, building the future to learn more about the research project: https://www.linkedin.com/company/86721040/
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate 'Dietetics, building the future'

profile_positions.description: I was involved with shaping the pilot design for Healthy Entrepreneurs within the ‘Making More Health’ initiative by Boeringher Ingelheim aimed at creating greater health access (https://www.makingmorehealth.org). The pilot is aimed at creating a doctor on demand application for non-communicable diseases that can be used by community health workers in rural Kenya.
profile_positions.title: Program Officer, Making More Health Pilot in rural Kenya

profile_positions.description:
Healthy Entrepreneurs operates through a network of micro entrepreneurs in remote areas of developing countries to distribute affordable medicines and health products and services to the families that need them most. Our entrepreneurs run small pharmacies and drugstores, and are equipped with solar-charged tablets loaded with educational videos and applications to support their business. We empower them to cover the last mile and reach the poorest families by integrating health education and the supply chain in one sustainable model.

I coordinated the operation in Ghana and managed the local staff. My responsibilities were to develop and improve the Healthy Entrepreneurs model within the Ghanaian context and to monitor and evaluate our activities. I closely cooperated with Ghana Health Service, Pharmacy Council Ghana and our local consortium partners (Solidaridad, HFFG and PRS&D).
profile_positions.title: Country Coordinator Ghana

company.name: MCNV - For health and development in South East Asia

profile_positions.company: MCNV - For health and development in South East Asia
profile_positions.description: Mixed methods study on malnutrition rehabilitation in Vietnamese ethnic minority children aged 6-59 months (approximately 1500 children in the intervention group and 1500 children in the control group). In the intervention, a locally produced cereal powder was used as supplementary food. For this study I assessed the change in nutritional status before and after the intervention. Furthermore, I researched utilization and delivery processes in a qualitative manner by interviewing mothers and health workers (23) and conducting focus group discussions with them.
profile_positions.title: MSc researcher

profile_positions.description: As part of my bachelor Nutrition and Dietetics I worked as an intern dietitian at Atrium Medical Center. I worked with clinical patients at all units, primarily the oncology unit. Furthermore, I worked on with outpatients with diabetes and patients who underwent bariatric surgery.
profile_positions.title: Intern Dietitian

profile_positions.description:
Mixed methods study into malnutrition among children aged 0-5 years in townships in Cape Town. 
-     A literature study in (mal)nutrition and food habits in South Africa
-     Assessing the nutritional status of 500 children, aged 0-5 years, in daycare centres in townships in Cape Town by measuring height, weight and middle upper arm circumference.
-     Development of an information booklet on child health which will be used by daycare centre leaders trained by Ikamva Labantu. This information booklet is based on previously used "integrated management of childhood illness strategy" developed by the WHO, USAID and South African Government. Since Ikamva Labuntu felt this strategy was dated, incomplete and too difficult to read, adaptions and additions were made in subjects, content and form of the booklet.
profile_positions.title: BSc researcher

company.name: IFMSA | International Federation of Medical Students'​ Associations

volunteer_experiences.description: Organising masterclasses for students about the Millennium Development Goals.

volunteer_experiences.role: Participant Youth Incentive, the international programme on Youth and Sexuality
volunteer_experiences.description: Participant in 'Youth Incentives', the international program on Youth and Sexuality, with the Rutgers Nisso Group as representative of the International Federation of Medical Students’ Associations (IFMSA). Together with 30 other representatives of international youth organizations I participated in focus group discussions to get in-depth insight into the most important problems/challenges young people face in developing countries concerning their sexual and reproductive health. We formulated essential and concrete advocacy messages on millennium goal 5b: Universal access to reproductive health, for the Advocacy Event which took place in October 2010 during the biannual conference on ‘young people and sexuality’.
Co-chair of the VU Model United Nations for international public health students in 2015 and 2016.

I was a life guard on the beach in Zeeland for 3 summers, doing walking patrols and boat patrols, providing first aid, handling communication with other life guard posts, following trainings on rescue swimming, sailing, first aid.
